speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the onset of your symptoms? When did you first start experiencing neck and arm pain, paresthesias, and muscle weakness?

speaker: Patient
text: "I started noticing the pain about a year ago, but it was just a dull ache at first. Over time, it's become more intense and has spread to my arms, and it's really been affecting my daily activities. I've also been experiencing these weird tingling sensations in my hands, like pins and needles."

speaker: Doctor
text: When did you first notice that these symptoms were worsening, and did you experience any triggers or events that could be linked to the onset of your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I started noticing that the pain and weakness were getting worse about 3 months ago, and it's been a steady decline since then. I had a few minor falls and bumps a few weeks ago, but nothing that I would associate with triggering these symptoms. However, I did have a bit of a stressful period a couple of months ago, and I've been under a lot of pressure at work lately."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your activities before the onset of these symptoms? Were you engaging in any strenuous activities, lifting heavy objects, or were you doing anything unusual that could have caused an injury or strain?

speaker: Patient
text: "I was working a 9-to-5 job, sitting for long hours, and didn't really engage in any strenuous activities, but I did have a job that involved some heavy lifting and bending, which I had to do occasionally. I also had a family history of physical labor, so I'm sure that had some impact on my overall health."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical examination, starting with a thorough neurological assessment to check for any abnormalities in your reflexes and sensation. Can you please place your hands under my table and lift your arms up, and I'll check your reflexes in your arms and legs?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll do that. I'm a bit nervous about the reflexes, to be honest. And I've been having some trouble holding my hands steady lately, so I'm not sure if you'll be able to get a good reading."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you please hold your arms straight out to the sides and lift them up so I can assess the range of motion and any potential deformities?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll try my best. *lifts arms straight out to the sides and up* Like this. I can feel a bit of numbness in my fingers, but it's not too bad. I'm not really sure if I should be worried about it, though."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to know more about your daily activities and any recent changes in your work or home environment. Have you noticed any changes in your posture, occupation, or daily routine that could be contributing to your symptoms?



Also, I'd like you to place your hands back under the table and I'll assess the muscle tone in your arms. Can you please hold your arms straight out to the sides and slowly lower them down, so I can check for any weakness?



Please also tell me, have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your hands or feet that radiates to other parts of your body?



REQUEST TEST: EMG

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the pain you're experiencing in your neck and arm? Is it a dull ache, sharp stabbing, or more of a burning sensation?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a burning sensation, to be honest. It's hard to describe, but it feels like someone is holding a hot iron to my skin, and it just won't go away. It's constant and persistent, even when I'm doing things that normally don't bother me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain in your neck and arm? Is it constant or does it come and go, and is it worse when you move your neck or arms?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's constant, to be honest. The burning sensation doesn't really change with movement, but sometimes it feels like it's more intense when I'm standing still for a long time. I've also noticed that the pain seems to be more noticeable when I'm trying to focus on something or concentrate on a task, like when I'm working on my computer."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of your responses so far. I'd like to know more about your daily activities. Are you involved in any physical activities, such as sports or heavy lifting, that could be contributing to the onset of your symptoms?



Can you also tell me about any recent illnesses or infections you've had, as well as any medications you're currently taking?



Also, I'd like to check your sensory function further. Can you please close your eyes and focus on a point in front of you, and I'll gently press on your skin to assess for any areas of numbness or tingling?



Also, REQUEST TEST: MRI

text:
Can you please describe the duration of the numbness and tingling sensations you've experienced? Are they constant, or do they come and go, and are they more noticeable at night or during the day?



Also, when you hold your arms straight out to the sides and lift them up, do you feel any pulling or stretching sensation in your shoulders or upper back?



I've reviewed the EMG results, and it appears there's some evidence of denervation in your arm muscles. Can you tell me more about your occupation and what kind of tasks you typically perform on a daily basis?



Can you please place your index fingers on a flat surface and spread them apart as far as possible, and then bring them back together, to help assess your finger function and dexterity?



Also, I'd like to know more about your sleep patterns. Do you experience any difficulty sleeping or restlessness due to your symptoms?



REQUEST TEST: Nerve Conduction Study (NCS)

text: Can you tell me more about your occupation and what kind of tasks you typically perform on a daily basis? Are you on your feet for long periods of time, or do you have a job that involves repetitive movements or lifting?

speaker: Patient
text: "I work as an administrative assistant, so I'm mostly sitting at a desk for long hours. I don't have a job that involves lifting heavy objects or repetitive movements, but I do have to type on a keyboard for hours a day, which can be tiring. I'm not on my feet for long periods of time, but I do take breaks to stand up and stretch."

text: Can you tell me more about the progression of your numbness and tingling sensations? Have they worsened or improved over time, and do you notice any patterns, such as being worse at night or after periods of inactivity?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been getting worse over time, to be honest. The numbness and tingling sensations are constant now, and they seem to be getting worse. I've noticed they're more pronounced at night, especially after I've been sitting for a long time. It's like my body is trying to tell me something, but I'm not sure what."

Sometimes it feels like it's spreading up my arm, and it can be really uncomfortable, like my skin is on fire."
